title-group.article-title: Viewpoint–participation–technique: A model of participative requirements elicitation

author-notes.corresp: Christopher Durugbo, Department of Management, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TN, UK. Email: christopher.durugbo@bristol.ac.uk

abstract.p: Requirements elicitation is an early phase process in systems development that captures user needs and represents them as a set of requirements. In view of increasing demand for products and services that target mass markets, requirements analysts have begun emphasising the need for participation of end users and customers during elicitation. This article proposes the viewpoint–participation–technique model of requirements elicitation that integrates functions for strategizing elicitation participation and selecting elicitation techniques. A step-by-step approach to using the viewpoint–participation–technique model is then presented, and the model is illustrated through a case study of the elicitation process for an interlibrary loan service. The article also discusses some applications and limitations of the viewpoint–participation–technique model and concludes by identifying possible future research directions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Requirements elicitation is an early phase process that is critical in requirements engineering (Chakraborty et al., 2010; Hickey and Davis, 2004; Minocha et al., 2008). It is characteristically carried out concurrently with other requirements engineering processes such as requirements analysis, validation and negotiation. This is because concurrency in requirements engineering lowers process overheads, facilitates the early identification and implementation of value-delivering requirements and improves responsiveness to changes in requirements (Sommerville, 2005).

Typical approaches to the requirements elicitation process begin with an assumption that requirements are clear, and the focus of the process is on the step-by-step transformation of requirements into specifications of a design. However, this is not generally the case and requirements analysts agree that because of this lack of clarity, the elicitation process must capture the viewpoints of a diverse range of stakeholders (Gambhir, 2001; Kirsch and Haney, 2006). Stakeholders are individuals, groups or organisations with stakes (e.g. involvement, concerns) in a system such as customers, end users, analysts, developers and testers (Minocha et al., 2008). Exploring the viewpoint of users is the motivation for user-centred design that meets the needs of specific end users such as older people or the visually impaired (Noyes and Baber, 1999; Sustar et al., 2008). Consequently, there is a need for a systematic approach to participation during requirements elicitation to capture viewpoints of stakeholders.

Participation enables stakeholders to express opinions and to take part in activities that contribute to the clarification of specifications. It is crucial to concurrent engineering, a practice that was initially proposed to minimise product design, development and delivery times and rework (Prasad, 1999). This is because the ‘taking part’ determines how processes are overlapped and how multidisciplinary or cross-functional teams are structured and supported (Durugbo, 2012; Meredith and Kleiner, 2006). Furthermore, analysts have begun emphasising the need for involving customers and end users for active roles during requirements engineering processes (Jiao and Chen, 2006; Withanage et al., 2010). This is because failures in requirements engineering have been traced to inadequate considerations for human factors (Fuentes-Fernández et al., 2010; Garmer et al., 2004). Participation also enhances the dynamics of interaction among stakeholders (Chakraborty et al., 2010) leading to improved communication, better integration of perspectives and greater levels of stakeholder involvement (Decker et al., 2007). Then again, participation when unmanaged or misunderstood can have negative effects such as user–developer conflict and communication lapses (He and King, 2008).

In this article, a conceptual model – termed the viewpoint–participation–technique (ViPaTe) model – is proposed to formalise the dynamics of elicitation as a process in which participation is strategized and techniques for use in involving participants are selected. Whereas insights into participation during requirements elicitation will improve the attitude of stakeholders (Geisser and Hildenbrand, 2006; He and King, 2008) and the level of support for concurrent requirements engineering (Meredith and Kleiner, 2006; Sommerville, 2005), the quality of requirements is enhanced by better understanding of the elicitation process and elicitation technique selection factors (Hickey and Davis, 2004). Furthermore, the formalisation of concepts associated with systems development is an area of research that has recently been emphasised in the literature through themes such as security requirements of information systems (Gerber et al., 2001), technique selection during elicitation (Hickey and Davis, 2004), trust in virtual communities (De Moor and Weigand, 2007), confidence during requirements analysis (Boness et al., 2011) and user participation within organisations (Durugbo, 2012).

The remainder of the article is organised as follows: section ‘The ViPaTe model of requirements elicitation’ describes the ViPaTe model that conceptualises requirements elicitation in relation to participation and technique selected, the ‘Discussion’ section discusses some applications and limitations of the ViPaTe model and the ‘Conclusion’ section concludes by highlighting possible future research directions.

sec.title: The ViPaTe model of requirements elicitation
sec.p: This article proposes the ViPaTe model of the requirements elicitation process that formally conceptualises participation of stakeholders and technique selection. To do this, the unified model of elicitation by Hickey and Davis (2004) was selected as the foundation on which further concepts would be introduced in the ViPaTe model. This selection was based on two main factors.

First, the unified model proposes a generic view of the elicitation process using characteristics of the problem/solution and project domains. The model emphasises the role of these domains for selecting elicitation techniques based on situational characteristics that drive decision processes. The model also highlights the role of knowledge for elicitation by identifying three main sources:

list-item.p: knowledge of the characteristics of existing problems, solutions and projects,
knowledge of known and unknown requirements and
knowledge of the links between the characteristics of existing problems, solutions and projects, known/unknown requirements and elicitation technique selection.

Selecting existing models and extending them for use in characterising aspects of the elicitation process is typical of model development approaches found in academic literature (such as Aranda et al., 2010; Hickey and Davis, 2004). In these approaches, conceptual models are complemented with prescribed step-by-step directions to guide analysts/researchers in using the proposed models.

The ViPaTe model of the elicitation process proposed in this article, as shown in Figure 1, concentrates on human factors by adding an elicitation participation strategy that enables stakeholders reach an agreement on requirements. The ViPaTe model modifies the elicitation technique selection process model proposed in Hickey and Davis (2004) by extending it to include a model of negotiation during participative elicitation. In addition, a prescribed step-by-step approach to using the ViPaTe model is presented. To illustrate the use of the ViPaTe model, an example from our previous study (Durugbo et al., 2010) is presented and analysed. The example, based on the elicitation of requirements for the information system of the Cranfield University Interlibrary loan service, was selected for familiarity purposes, as it presents a case that most researchers can relate to and it enables the reader gain an appreciation of how to apply the ViPaTe model. The example shows how the ViPaTe model can be used to formalise elicitation processes and elicitation methodologies with regard to elicitation participation strategy and elicitation technique selection.

sec.title: Functions of the ViPaTe model
sec.p: Participative requirements elicitation, in this article, is conceptualised as a set of activities that acquire and represent individual requirements that involve, precede or follow a bringing together phase for stakeholders to discuss and match different perspectives and interests, as shown by Figure 1.

The ‘acquisition phase’ of elicitation is dependent on unsolved problems of stakeholders and involves gaining access to data/information for learning about, uncovering, extracting, surfacing or discovering requirements. The ‘represent phase’ involves depicting the findings of the acquisition phase in deliverables through the use of scenario diagrams, prototypes, log files and so on. The ‘bringing together phase’ involves an iteration of the ‘acquire’ and ‘represent’ phases with stakeholders for matching and discussing perspectives and interests.

Different strategies can be adopted for these elicitation phases according to problem and domain knowledge. For instance, acquisition and/or elicitation phases can involve stakeholders as participants or these phases can be carried out by the analyst. These possibilities impact on the selection of techniques used to elicit requirements because depending on the strategy, an analyst may use one overall technique or several techniques for different phases. sec.title: Viewpoint (Vi)
sec.p: Viewpoints (Vi) at iterative stage i is a set of perspectives that capture what is required by stakeholders or the system to be developed. Examples include a security viewpoint (of a factory) for a stakeholder and a database viewpoint (of sales) for an organisation (Sommerville and Sawyer, 1997). A viewpoint involves clearly identifying a definiendum (concept to be defined) and its definiens (elements or properties that define a concept). In systems development, the definiendum is typically designs of architectures or processes for systems. The definiens, on the other hand, includes elements such as system components or properties such as system states. Viewpoints are widely used in requirements elicitation (e.g. Hanneghan et al., 2000; Sommerville and Sawyer, 1997) and are important for addressing ‘the multiple perspective problem’ that generates conflicts during concurrent requirements engineering (Easterbrook et al., 1994; Sommerville and Sawyer, 1997).

Various permutations for viewpoints may exist. For instance, grouped stakeholders (such as users) or subsets of grouped stakeholders (such as intermediate users and advanced users) may have different viewpoints, and different stakeholders may have common or different viewpoints. For the system to be developed, the main viewpoints include structural and behavioural perspectives (see, for instance, Durugbo, 2012). The structural perspective identifies elements, organisations and interconnections that produce the architecture of the system. The behavioural perspective identifies activities, scenarios and states that contribute to the functions of the systems. These different viewpoints are useful in eliciting requirements and may involve complicated relationships and links.

sec.title: Technique (τi)
sec.p: A technique (τi) is the procedure for collectively accomplishing something and is often done through the use of tools such as software programs and websites. These techniques can be categorised according to their use for acquisition, representation or both. Acquisition techniques include observation, introspection and shadowing, through the use of communication channels such as face-to-face interaction, telephone conversations and video conferencing. Representation techniques (such as user diaries, prototyping and functional narratives) combine or exclusively use textual, mathematical or diagrammatical reasoning as well as artefacts. Techniques for acquiring and representing requirements include ethnography, goal-based analysis and cognitive work analysis. Due to the emphasis of the ViPaTe model on participation, elicitation techniques selection need to take into account active stakeholders willing to participate during elicitation. These active stakeholders could be analysts, managers, end users and so on. sec.title: Using the ViPaTe model: an interlibrary loan system
sec.p: In this section, a case study from literature is presented and applied to show how the ViPaTe model can be used as an analytical approach for elicitation methodologies.

sec.title: Overview of the interlibrary loan system
sec.p: Durugbo et al. (2010), applied to exemplify the use of the ViPaTe model proposed in this article, is based on the analysis of the interlibrary loan service provided by the Cranfield University Library (CUL). CUL delivers integrated products and services as solutions for clients (students, staff and university visitors). The products offered by the CUL include books, reports, articles and magazines. Services for the CUL include book borrowing, technical help to students, interlibrary loans, book purchasing, training, provision of specialist subject information and provision of offsite services. However, the interlibrary loan service of the CUL was based on outsourcing the provision of journals to other libraries and sources, on behalf of the student.

The study focused on eliciting and analysing the information needs (i.e. the requirements) for an improved information system to deliver the interlibrary loan service. In order to accomplish this, Durugbo et al. (2010) analysed the existing information system through interviews with eight librarians at the CUL and created data flow diagrams to model information flow for the interlibrary loan service. This involved an iteration to elicit the requirements of a TO-BE model (based on an AS-IS model) of an information system for the interlibrary loan service, as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Data flow diagrams for the AS-IS and possible TO-BE models of the information system for the interlibrary loan service.

sec.p: The requirements highlighted by the proposed TO-BE model of Figure 2 involve reconfiguring the existing information system through aggregating and restructuring information. In this TO-BE model, students are co-opted and trained to supply an ISSN number used to uniquely identify most journals. This ensures that a journal can be effectively identified by a student in the library (internal) catalogue. This minimises data uncertainties associated with filling the wrong interlibrary request form and not filling enough data for enabling librarians to place orders for interlibrary loans. The reader is referred to Durugbo et al. (2010) for a discussion of the changes from the AS-IS to the TO-BE model and impacts of the TO-BE model. Since the ViPaTe model is proposed in this article, the model did not help in the change from the AS-IS model to the TO-BE model. As mentioned earlier, the ViPaTe model is intended to formalise the dynamics of elicitation as a process in which participation is strategized and techniques for use in involving participants are selected. It provides an alternative mathematical form (other forms being diagrammatical, textual and physical forms) for describing the elicitation process – not the process for system development or redesign.

sec.title: Formalising the requirements elicitation process
sec.p: Using the proposed ViPaTe model of participative elicitation, the elicitation stages (n = 2) within Durugbo et al. (2010) are illustrated as follows:

list-item.p: Viewpoint assessment: the main viewpoints (V) were the information system viewpoints identified by the analysts and the user and loan staff viewpoints provided by three interlibrary loan staff.

Participation scope: in this step, the span for participation centred on sequential and individual activities (A1 and A2) for acquisition, representation and bringing together. Two analysts P actively took part in all activities. Interlibrary loan staff actively participated during acquisition. The main constraint c (i.e. c1 and c2) for the project was the availability (time) of interlibrary loan staff. Agreement for the first step (g1) was reached through face-to-face interactions, and agreement for the second step (g2) was reached through email exchanges.

Requirements status: using step 1, the a posterior requirements (R1) (e.g. the system should enable students identify journals) were based on the AS-IS state of the information systems and the a posteriori (R2) (e.g. the system should enable students place orders for journals) were based on the TO-BE state of the proposed information system, as shown in Figure 2.

for the problem – uncertainty created while sharing data between the student (making the request) and the librarian (processing the data to deliver an order);
for the solution – the flow of information for the interlibrary loan system and

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Requirements elicitation can be a crucial and challenging task. This is because elicitation initiates requirements engineering and generates initial requirements that are analysed, validated, documented and managed to produce a final specification. Furthermore, the elicitation process can be iterative and may contain negotiation stages that involve the participation of a wide range of users with different needs and perspectives of the system.

Models of the elicitation process should therefore consider participation strategies to facilitate sequential and concurrent processes alike. Participation to accomplish tasks centres on activities performed by individuals (Durugbo, 2012), and in the elicitation process, these activities are determined by the viewpoints of participants (Decker et al., 2007), constraints of projects and negotiation that enable people to work together (Soares et al., 2011; Tsumaki and Tamai, 2006). Furthermore, elicitation in general, as suggested by Hickey and Davis (2004), requires functions to select techniques based on the situation of problems, solutions and project domains. This selection must reflect the preference of key participants such as analysts and users and the characteristics of the techniques to be used to acquire and represent requirements.

Along these lines, the ViPaTe model of participative requirements elicitation has been proposed, in this article, to formalise the elicitation process in relation to elicitation participation strategies and elicitation technique selection. The elicitation process was analysed as an amalgamation of activities for the acquisition and representation of requirements according to viewpoints that address system and stakeholder needs. The ViPaTe model also conceptualised a stage of bringing stakeholders together that can be done before, during or after different acquisition and representation activities and is determined by the situation of the project to elicit requirements, problems and solutions. The applications of the model for researchers/practitioners and limitations of the model are discussed in the next subsections.

sec.title: Applications of the ViPaTe model
sec.p: Researchers and practitioners can use the ViPaTe model in two main ways: as an analytical approach to represent an elicitation methodology and as a groundwork approach to plan the different stages of a proposed ViPaTe model.

As shown through the case study of the Cranfield University interlibrary loan service (section ‘Using the ViPaTe model: an interlibrary loan system’), methodologies used for elicitation can be formalised using the ViPaTe model. The formalisation is done mathematically to reveal mathematical properties for participative elicitation processes. This enables researchers and practitioners to formalise their elicitation methodologies, as shown through equations (11) and (12). The use of the ViPaTe model could also be extended for comparative analysis of industry practice with regard to elicitation processes, elicitation participation and elicitation techniques.

Factors relating to problem, solution and project domains have been shown to serve as a useful basis for selecting techniques (Hickey and Davis, 2004). Similarly, through the ViPaTe model, further considerations for human factors have been used to emphasise the role of viewpoints for strategizing participation. The prescribed steps for using the ViPaTe model outlined in section ‘Prescribed steps for using the ViPaTe model’ position participation as an important aspect for the elicitation process.

sec.title: Limitations of the ViPaTe model
sec.p: As mentioned earlier, participation plays an important role in the dynamics of interaction among stakeholders but may lead to conflicts and communication lapses. In addition, the ViPaTe model of elicitation incorporates system and stakeholder viewpoints during elicitation (see Figure 1). Consequently, there is a need to augment the model with other useful viewpoints such as information and infrastructure perspectives of systems to be developed. The reference model for open distributed processing and the concurrent engineering reference model are examples of architectural frameworks that incorporate information and infrastructure viewpoints (Hanneghan et al., 2000).

Combining and formalising these views could lead to a more comprehensive model that fulfils the needs of requirements elicitation across industry sectors promoting concurrency of requirements engineering processes and interoperability across industrial sectors. Additional considerations are also required for the management of elicitation and the mental models and expectations that lead to stakeholder viewpoints. This is because differing expectations of stakeholders make elicitation difficult and challenging (Laporti et al., 2009). Uncertainties in user needs can also raise management expectations that may not reflect the actual needs of elicitation. In addition, the proposed mathematical formulations consider the dynamics associated with elicitation viewpoints and situations, but aspects such as integrity, privacy and confidentiality associated with interactions are not prescribed.

Beyond the elicitation process, there is a need to review the role of participation. This is because requirements engineering processes vary in terms of their dependencies. This has significant implications for concurrent engineering. Although participation plays an important role in achieving the objectives of concurrent engineering and concurrent requirements engineering, the management of requirements, for instance, is an important challenge for concurrent engineering (Lin et al. 1996). Furthermore, concurrent requirements engineering may not be suitable for all types of systems such as during the development of critical systems (Sommerville, 2005). Nonetheless, for business systems that support concurrency during requirements engineering, participation is vital to carrying out concurrent activities and to providing feedback and synchronicity of complex, iterative and sociotechnological processes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Prior work by authors such as Aranda et al. (2010), Coughlan and Macredie (2002) and Hickey and Davis (2004) have selected, extended and evaluated conceptual models for eliciting requirements. These studies have adopted a generic approach in which no specific technique or tool is targeted. Similarly, this article has proposed and illustrated the ViPaTe model for formalising elicitation processes that are based on participation among stakeholders for developing products and services that meet the demands of mass markets. However, challenges exist to explore usability, viewpoints and management aspects of the ViPaTe model.

list-item.p: Usability of elicitation process model: in this article, a case study involving the use of the ViPaTe model for analysing elicitation methodologies has been presented. This presented a formal view of the methodology within the case through mathematical formulations. There is therefore a need to examine the use of the model as a groundwork approach and to explore diagrammatical reasoning as a means of complementing the proposed mathematical formalisations.

Viewpoints of requirements: the ViPaTe model concentrates on systems and stakeholder viewpoints, that is, it deals with sociotechnical systems. Further work is therefore needed to characterise viewpoints of other forms of systems such as real-time and event-driven systems. Mechanisms (such as taxonomies and ontology) to facilitate correlations between viewpoints could also be explored to improve elicitation negotiations.

Management of elicitation participation: in the ViPaTe model, participation is a subset of activities for acquiring and representing requirements. Decision-making, communication and work are the main activities from which participation was derived. The ViPaTe model also emphasises the role of project constraints, preference of key participant and consensus among stakeholders. These factors can be used as ‘research lenses’ to expose possible research directions for participative elicitation. For instance, exploring the preference of key participants for certain communication channels (such as face-to-face interaction, telephone conversations or emails) raises research questions under themes such as ‘social presence and media richness’ (Yoo and Alavi, 2001) that have impacts on participation among stakeholders.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Christopher Durugbo is a Lecturer in Management at the University of Bristol. He received a BEng in Interactive Systems from the University of Birmingham in 2007 and a PhD in Applied Sciences from Cranfield University in 2012. His research focuses on systems and network analysis, service operations management, engineering design, information and technology management, and human factors, and he has published findings from his research in several journals such as Expert Systems with Applications, Systems Engineering, Information Sciences, International Journal of Production Research, Ergonomics, International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology, and Journal of Intelligent Manufacturing.

Johann c.k.h. Riedel is a Senior Research Fellow within the Centre for Concurrent Enterprise at the University of Nottingham. His research focuses on product design and development, management of engineering design, knowledge in design, innovation, learning and simulation, including games, for design and innovation, ICT and design, collaboration, performance measurement and readiness assessment. He has published findings from his research in several journals such as Journal of Product Innovation Management, R&D Management, Journal of Manufacturing Technology Management, International Journal of Operations and Production Management, and International Journal of Production Research.
